content.content: If someone cannot afford to slaughter two goats for his son, one will also suffice.
One can also have shares of aqeeqah in a sacrificial camel or other animals.

body.content: Aqeeqah is Sunnah mustahabbah (recommended but not obligatory). If you can afford it, you should do it. If not, you will not be a sinner, but will miss the reward.

content.content: It is Sunnah to perform aqeeqah on the 7th day of birth (preferable). It can also be performed on the 14th or 21st day.
If someone cannot perform it on these days, they can perform it whenever possible. The Sunnah will still be fulfilled.

body.content: If someone's aqeeqah was never performed, they can perform it themselves in youth or old age.

content.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
performed his own aqeeqah after the declaration of prophethood.

If you don't remember your child's birth date, consider the day preceding the birthday as the seventh day. For example, if the child was born on Friday, then every Thursday is considered the seventh day.

references.source: Musannaf Abdul Razzaq, vol. 4, p. 254, Hadith 2174

body.content:
It is better not to break the bones of the aqeeqah animal, but rather remove meat from the bones. This bodes well for the child's safety. If the meat is cooked after breaking bones, there is no harm.

The meat can be cooked in any way, but cooking it with a sweet taste is a good omen for the child to be well-mannered.

content.content:
Sweet Meat Cooking Methods:

1. Pour oil or ghee as needed and combine one kilogram of meat, half a kilogram of sweetened yogurt, 7 pieces of cardamom, and 50 grams of almond in a pot. Cook all ingredients, then add sugar as needed. For garnishing, add finely chopped carrots and raisins.

2. Put half a kilogram of beetroot with one kilogram of meat in a pot and cook in the usual way.

body.content:
Parents and grandparents (both paternal and maternal) may eat the meat of aqeeqah. The belief that they should not is incorrect and has no proof.

The raw meat can be distributed among the poor, relatives, and close friends. It can also be given to them after cooking, or served at a feast. All these methods are permissible.

Do not feed aqeeqah meat to kites and crows, as they are fasiq (disobedient/impure).

The aqeeqah animal should meet the same conditions as stipulated for the sacrificial animal.

The rulings for the skin of the aqeeqah animal are the same as for sacrificial animals. It can be used personally, given to the needy, or donated to a good cause like a masjid or madrasah.

Aqeeqah is performed in gratitude for birth; therefore, it cannot be performed after death.
When performing aqeeqah for a boy, the father should slaughter the animal and recite this supplication:

اللَّهُمَّ هَذِهِ عَقِيقَةُ ابْنِي فُلَان، دَمُهَا بِدَمِهِ، وَلَحْمُهَا بِلَحْمِهِ، وَعَظْمُهَا بِعَظْمِهِ، وَجِلْدُهَا بِجِلْدِهِ، وَشَعْرُهَا بِشَعْرِهِ، اللَّهُمَّ اجْعَلْنَا فِدَاءً لِابْنِي مِنَ النَّارِ، بِسْمِ اللهِ، اللهُ أَكْبَرُ
Instead of saying "so-and-so," mention the name of the son.

content.content: For a daughter, say the word
بِنْتِ
instead of
اِبْنِ
at both places and
ها
instead of
هِ
at five places.
If anyone other than the father slaughters the animal, they should replace
اِبْنِ فُلَان
or
بِنْتِ فُلَان
with
فُلَان اِبْنِ فُلَان
or
فُلَان بِنْتِ فُلَان
. The boy should be related to his father and the girl to her mother.
If you don't remember the supplication, just mentally intend that this is the aqeeqah of so-and-so boy or girl. Then recite
بِسْمِ اللهِ اللهُ أَكْبَرُ
and slaughter the animal. The aqeeqah will be valid as a supplication is not required.

body.content:
It is customary to invite relatives to the aqeeqah ceremony and serve them a feast, which is a good practice. Guests often bring gifts for the child, which is also fine.

However, hosts should not speak ill of guests who don't bring gifts. If a guest fears such treatment, they may choose not to attend unless necessary, and should bring a gift if they do attend.

If the host expects gifts and would speak ill of guests who don't bring them, receiving such gifts becomes a form of bribery and is sinful. However, if the host has no such expectations or habits, there is no harm in receiving gifts.

sunnahs.title: Choose Good Names for Your Children

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "Name [the child] after good people."

content.content: Mufti Muhammad Amjad Ali A'zami
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه

said: "A child should be given a good name. In the subcontinent, many people have names which have no meanings or bad meanings. Therefore, refrain from such names. It is better to name a child after blessed prophets
عَلَيْهِمُ الصَّلَاةُ وَالسَّلَامُ
, blessed companions, tabi'een and pious predecessors
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ
. It is hoped that the child will receive blessing from them."

body.content: Whether the child is born alive or stillborn, his body is formed completely or not, he should be named; he will be raised on Judgement Day.

content.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "Name the fetus from a miscarriage, as Allah Almighty will make your meezan (i.e. the balance of deeds) heavy through him."

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The one who has been blessed with the birth of a son and he names him 'Muhammad' due to my love and for gaining blessing of my name, both his son and he will go to Paradise."

content.content: "On Judgement Day, two people will be made to stand before Allah Almighty. It will be ordered: 'Take them to Paradise.' They will humbly say: 'O Allah Almighty! For which deed are we being sent to Paradise? We did not perform any deed that should lead us to Paradise!' Allah Almighty will say: 'Go to Paradise; I have taken the oath that the person whose name is Ahmed or Muhammad will not go to Hell.'"

sunnahs.title: The Blessing of Having a Muhammad in a Gathering

body.content: It has been narrated that if some people gather for a consultation about some issue including a person named Muhammad, but the people do not get any advice from him [the person whose name is Muhammad], they will not succeed in achieving their target.

references.source: Hashiyah Ala Al-Jami' Al-Sagheer, vol. 1, p. 149

body.content: A Tabi'i predecessor, Imam Atta
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
said: "The one who wants a male child from his pregnant wife should keep his hand on the belly of his [pregnant] wife and say: 'If it is a boy, I have named him Muhammad.'
إِنْ شَاءَ الله
A male child will be born."

references.source: Fatawa Razawiyyah, vol. 24, p. 690, slightly amended

body.content: Nowadays,
مَعَاذَ الله

names are being distorted commonly, and it is very painful to distort the name 'Muhammad'. So, name every male child Muhammad or Ahmed, but for calling them, give them first names after pious predecessors. The pronunciation of the names should be easy.
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "Do not name [the child] after angels."

content.content: However, if you want, you can name [your child] Ghulam Yaseen and Ghulam Taha.

body.content: Whenever you choose a name, ask any Sunni Islamic scholar about its meaning. Do not choose a name which has bad meanings. For example, Ghafoor-ud-din means the eliminator of the religion; it is very bad to choose this name. Bad names have a bad effect.

content.content: A'la Hazrat
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه

said: "I have seen myself how bad names have a very bad effect. I have also discovered a devout Sunni who conceals their faith and exerts efforts to spread corrupt beliefs in the twilight of their life."

sunnahs.title: Effects of Names on Future Generations

body.content: The effects of the name can be on the future generation as well.

content.content: It has been narrated by Saeed Bin Musayyab
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
in Sahih Bukhari: My grandfather went to the court of the beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
. He (
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
) asked, 'What is your name?' My grandfather replied, 'Huzn.' The Beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said, 'You are Sahl.' i.e. name yourself Sahl, which means soft, and Huzn means hard. My grandfather said, 'I will not change the name which my father has given.' Saeed Bin Musayyab
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
said, 'As a result, we still have hardness.'

sunnahs.title: Be Cautious with Names Beginning with 'Abdul'

body.content: In Part 15 of 'Bahar-e-Shari'at', it is stated: Abdullah and Abdul Rahman are very good names, but in this age, it has quite often been observed that instead of calling the person whose name is Abdul Rahman by his name Abdul Rahman, many people call him Rehman, and it is haraam to call anyone 'Rehman' other than God. Similarly, people call Abdul Khaliq 'Khaliq' and Abdul Ma'bood 'Ma'bood'. Such an impermissible change should not be made at all in such types of names. Likewise, there is a trend of shortening names, i.e. people spoil names in a way that is insulting. Such names should not be shortened at all. So when there is a likelihood that names will be shortened, such names should not be chosen, but rather other names should be chosen.

sunnahs.title: Changing Bad Names to Good Ones

body.content: Bad names should be replaced with good names because the beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
would change a bad name [with a good name].

content.content: There was a woman whose name was Asia [sinful]; the Beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
changed her name to Jameelah.

body.content: Such names are forbidden by which one can praise himself. In verse 32 of Surah Najm, part 27, Allah Almighty has said:
فَلَا تُزَكُّوا أَنفُسَكُمْ
"Therefore do not make the claim of yourselves to be pure."

content.content: It is stated in Muslim Sharif; The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
changed the name of a woman named 'Barrah' [i.e. righteous woman] to 'Zaynab' and said, 'Do not praise yourself. Allah Almighty knows very well who among you are righteous.'

body.content: It is not permissible to choose such names which are specific to non-Muslims. From Fatawa-e-Razawiyyah: There are types of names which are specific to disbelievers, such as Jirjis, Putrus, Yuhanna, etc. Therefore, it is not permissible for Muslims to choose such types of names [for their children], because it has a resemblance to disbelievers.

content.content: والله تعالى اغلم

body.content: It is permissible to name [the child] Ghulam Muhammad and Ahmed Jaan, but it is preferable not to add Ghulam or Jaan, etc. so that one can attain the virtues of the names 'Muhammad' and 'Ahmed' mentioned in blessed Ahadith. It is permissible to choose the names like Ghulam Rasool, Ghulam Siddique, Ghulam Ali, Ghulam Hussain, Ghulam Ghaus and Ghulam Raza.

A traveller, as per Shariah, is a person who, with the intention to travel the distance of three days, goes out of his place of residence, such as his city or village. Travelling by land for three days means the distance of fifty-seven and a half miles (i.e. approximately 92 kilometers).
For one making a Shar'i journey, it is necessary to have learnt the rulings needed during travel.
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
set out on Thursday for the Battle of Tabuk, and he
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
would prefer to set out on Thursdays.

content.content: When you have to travel, it is better to travel on Monday, Thursday or Saturday.

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
urged Sayyiduna Jubair Bin Mut'im
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه

to read these surahs to remain more prosperous than his companions on a journey:

1. Surah Al-Kafiroon
2. Surah Al-Nasr
3. Surah Al-Ikhlaas
4. Surah Al-Falaq
5. Surah Al-Naas

Recite all the surahs one time; recite
بِسْمِ اللهِ الرَّحْمٰنِ الرَّحِيمِ
before every surah and one time after all the surahs (in this way, you will recite five surahs and recite
بِسْمِ اللّٰه
6 times).

content.content: Sayyiduna Jubair Bin Mut'im
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه

said, 'I was well-to-do, but when I travelled, I would become less prosperous than my mates. I started reciting the above-mentioned surahs whenever I travelled. By virtue of their blessing, I would remain prosperous and wealthy until I would return.'

references.source: Abu Ya'la, vol. 6, p. 265, Hadith 7382, summarised

body.content: At the time of setting out, meet all your relatives and friends and seek their forgiveness for your mistakes. After this, it becomes compulsory for them to forgive you from the heart.

After putting on travelling clothes, offer 4 rak'aat nafl salah with Surah Al-Fatihah and Surah Al-Ikhlaas and then set out. By virtue of these rak'aat, your family and wealth will stay safe until your return.

content.content: Two rak'aat can also be offered. It is stated in a blessed Hadith, 'No one has left with his family anything better than the two rak'aat which he has offered at home at the time of making an intention to travel.'

references.source: Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah, vol. 1, p. 529

body.content: If there are three or more Islamic brothers travelling, they should make one their head as it is a Sunnah. It is stated in a blessed Hadith: "When there are three people on a journey, make one your head."

content.content: In this way, activities are managed properly. That person should be made the head who is well-mannered, wise and religious. The head should prefer his mates' rest over his rest.

body.content: One should keep a mirror, kohl, a comb and a miswak on a journey as it is a Sunnah.

content.content: The father of A'la Hazrat
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
, Mufti Naqi Ali Khan
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
, has written: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

would keep:

1. A miswak
2. Kohl
3. A mirror
4. A comb
5. Scissors
6. A needle
7. Thread
In another narration, the word 'oil' has also been mentioned.

body.content: Please yourself with the zikr of Allah Almighty because an angel will remain with you; but if you amuse yourself with [bad] poetry and vulgar conversation, Satan will be with you.
If you have a fear of your enemy or a robber, recite complete Surah Yāsīn. You will stay safe from every trouble.
إِنْ شَاءَ الله
. This practice is conclusively proven.
Whether you are travelling or not, whenever you feel any sorrow or have any trouble, recite
حَسْبُنَا اللهُ وَنِعْمَ الْوَكِيلُ
and
لَا حَوْلَ وَلَا قُوَّةَ إِلَّا بِاللهِ
in abundance.
إِنْ شَاءَ الله
You will get rid of the trouble.
During a journey, invoke
اللّٰهُ أَكْبَرُ
when you go upwards on a slope and invoke
سُبْحَانَ اللهِ
when you go downwards.
If someone is going on a journey, shake hands with the traveller and pray for him:
أَسْتَوْدِعُ اللَّهَ دِينَكَ، وَأَمَانَتَكَ، وَخَوَاتِيمَ عَمَلِكَ

sunnahs.title: Traveler's Dua for Those Staying Behind

body.content: For those who are not traveling, the traveller should make the following supplication:
أَسْتَوْدِعُكُمُ اللَّهَ الَّذِي لَا تَضِيعُ وَدَائِعُهُ
Recite the following when getting off at your destination:
الْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ الَّذِي سَلَّمَنِي وَالْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ الَّذِي آوَانِي وَالْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ الَّذِي لَمْ يَكِلْنِي إِلَى أَحَدٍ
The prayer made by a traveller is answered; therefore, pray for yourself, your parents, your family and other Muslims.
If someone falls ill or unconscious during a journey, his companions can spend from his possessions without any permission in order to fulfil his needs.
It is wajib for a traveller to do qasr in salah, i.e. offer two rak'aat salah in place of four rak'aat salah, because for him two rak'aat will be the complete salah.

content.content:
There is no qasr in Maghrib and Witr Salah.

There is no qasr in Sunnah salah, but rather all Sunnah salah will have to be offered. There is an exemption of Sunnah salah in the state of fear and anxiety, but they will be offered in the state of peace.

body.content: Try your best to travel by plane or train or bus, etc. at such a time when there is no salah time in between.
At sleeping times during the journey, do not be so negligent that
مَعَاذَ الله

you miss your salah.

Do not become heedless at all of salah even during a journey. Make wudu in advance, especially when travelling by plane, train and by bus that follows a long route.

If your bus breaks down on the way, have patience instead of putting your hereafter at risk by criticizing and speaking rubbish to the driver or the bus owner; instead, become busy with zikr and salat for attaining Paradise. The same can be done if your train or flight is late.

Keeping in mind the rights of other passengers travelling in the train, bus, etc., treat them with great kindness. Face difficulties yourself, but bring them comfort.

Do not get other passengers to have a low opinion of you by talking out loud and by laughing loudly.
If you see an old man or a Muslim patient on a bus, etc. that is crowded, insist on offering your seat with the intention to get reward.
Try your level best to travel by that bus or coach etc. in which films and music are not being played.
On return from your journey, bring some gifts for your family. The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
has said, 'When someone returns from a journey, he should bring some gift for his family, no matter if he carried some stones even.'
If it is not makruh time when you return from a Shar'i journey, offer two rak'aat nafl salah, first of all in your masjid and then at home after reaching home.

sunnahs.title: The Command to Visit the Sick

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "
عُودُوا الْمَرِيضَ
(Visit the patient)

sunnahs.title: Divine Rewards for Visiting the Sick

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

said: "Whoever visits a patient, Allah Almighty bestows a shadow of 75,000 angels on him, and for every step he takes, Allah Almighty writes one virtue for him, and for every step he takes, Allah Almighty removes one sin of his and elevates one rank until he sits at his place. When he sits, mercy covers him and will continue to cover him until he returns to his home."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "Whoever visits a patient, a caller calls from the sky, 'Good news is for you; your walking is good, and you have made a place for yourself in Paradise.'"

sunnahs.title: Angels Pray for Those Who Visit the Sick

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

said: "If a Muslim visits a sick Muslim in the morning, 70,000 angels pray for forgiveness for him until the evening, and if he visits in the evening, 70,000 angels pray for forgiveness for him until the morning, and for him there will be a garden in Paradise."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The one who makes proper wudu and then visits his (sick) Muslim brother with the intention to get reward will be moved away from Hell [equal to] the distance of 70 years."

sunnahs.title: Ask the Sick to Pray for You

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "When you visit a patient, ask him to pray for you, as his prayer is like the prayer of angels."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The prayer made by a patient is not rejected until he recovers."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "When a Muslim visits an ill Muslim, he should recite the following supplication 7 times:
أَسْأَلُ اللهَ الْعَظِيمَ رَبَّ الْعَرْشِ الْعَظِيمِ أَنْ يَشْفِيَكَ
If his death (time) has not come, he will be cured."

sunnahs.title: The Definition of Visiting the Sick

body.content: The literal meaning is to inquire after the health of a sick person by going to him.

sunnahs.title: Be Considerate of the Patient's Comfort

body.content: Visiting a patient is a Sunnah. If you feel that your visit will be inconvenient for the patient, do not visit him.
Even if you have strained relations with the patient or you do not like him, you should still visit him.
Visit the patient purely with the intention of following the Sunnah. If you visit a patient merely for the reason that he will also visit you when you fall ill, you will not get the reward.

If you visit a patient and notice his severe illness, do not talk to him in such a way that he feels fear, e.g., 'You are in a critical condition!' Nor should you shake your head in such a way that indicates he is in a serious condition.
At the time of visiting, show distress and sorrow from your facial expressions according to the situation in front of the patient or the grieved person.
Never talk in such a way that the patient or his attendant has the satanic whisper that you are happy with his problem.
Express your sympathy to the patient's family members as well and offer them all possible assistance or cooperation.
Visit the patient and inquire after him and pray for his recovery and safety.

sunnahs.title: The Prophet's ﷺ Prayer for the Sick

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
had a blessed habit. Whenever he
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
visited a patient, he
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
would recite: "
لَا بَأْسَ طَهُورٌ إِنْ شَاءَ اللهُ
Ask the patient to pray for you, as a patient's prayer is not rejected.

sunnahs.title: The Proper Way to Inquire About Health

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The proper way of inquiring after an ill person is that you place your hand on his forehead and ask him how he is."

sunnahs.title: Placing Hand as an Expression of Love

body.content: Regarding this blessed Hadith, Mufti Ahmad Yar Khan
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه

said: "When anyone visits a patient, he should place his hand on the patient's forehead and say, 'How are you?' This consoles the patient, but he should avoid placing his hand for so long. This act of placing a hand is a way to express love."
If the patient feels discomfort when you place your hand on his forehead, do not place your hand. If the patient is a beardless attractive boy (even if he is not such) and you
مَعَاذَ الله
feel lust when you place your hand, your act of placing a hand is a sin. If you feel lust by looking at him, your act of looking is also haraam.

A polite and pleasant conversation should be made in front of the patient so that he can be pleased. Mention the virtues of illness and talk about the mercy of Allah Almighty so that he can focus his attention on the reward of Hereafter and avoid making complaints.

When visiting the patient, present him the call to righteousness according to the situation. In particular, persuade him to offer salah regularly, because during the period of illness, even many salah-offering people also become heedless of salah.
Do not stay long with the patient, and do not make a noise either. However, if the patient wants you to spend more time with him, you may do so if possible, respecting his wish.

Some people have a habit of prescribing medicines to the patient. The patient should not receive treatment prescribed by any ordinary person. Remember! Those who are not doctors but prescribe medicines are sinful.
A'la Hazrat
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
said: "It is Haraam for the one who is not a doctor (نااہل) to prescribe medicines, and it is obligatory for him to give up prescribing medicines."

content.content: It is Haraam for the one who is not a doctor to prescribe medicines, and it is obligatory for him to give up prescribing medicines.

body.content: Taking fruit or biscuits, etc. as a gift to the patient when visiting him is a good act. However, avoiding the visit because of having nothing to present and thinking that 'If you visit the patient empty-handed, he will mind' is not good.

When visiting a patient, some people take a bouquet, which is also permissible, but it is better to give something that is useful. Consider giving Islamic booklets that can benefit the patient and others around them.
Visiting a transgressor (فاسق) is also permissible because it is an Islamic right of every Muslim, and a transgressor is also a Muslim.
It is not permissible to visit a sick apostate and harbi disbeliever. (At the present time, all disbelievers are harbi in the world.)
It is forbidden to visit a heretic person whose heretic practices have not reached disbelief yet.
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The one who arranges a shroud for the deceased, for him there is one virtue for every hair of the deceased."

content.content: Allamah Abdul Rauf Munaawi
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
has clarified: "This refers to one who arranges a shroud for the deceased out of his own pocket."

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The one who arranges a shroud for the deceased, Allah Almighty will make him wear light and heavy silk dress in Paradise."

sunnahs.title: Complete Forgiveness Through Service to the Deceased

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

said: "The one who bathes, shrouds, applies fragrance to the deceased, carries his bier, offers his [funeral] salah and conceals anything bad related to him gets rid of his sins as [he was] on the day when he was borne by his mother."

content.content: "Anything bad" refers to things that should not be disclosed, such as the face complexion turning dark.

sunnahs.title: Good Shrouds Bring Joy in the Grave

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "Arrange good shrouds for your deceased people, because they meet each other in their graves and feel happy due to [their] good shrouds."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "When anyone amongst you arranges a shroud for his brother, he should arrange a good shroud for him."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "Arrange a white shroud for your deceased ones."

The intention of shrouding the deceased: "For pleasing Allah Almighty and for performing the mandatory act, I will shroud the deceased as per Sunnah and by thinking about the shroud which I will be made to wear after my death."
It is 'fard kifayah' to arrange a shroud for the deceased.

content.content: This means if anyone arranges a shroud for the deceased, all people will be exempted from this mandatory act. Otherwise, all those who received the news but did not arrange a shroud will be sinners.

body.content:
For Men:

1. Lifafah (sheet)
2. Izaar (lower garment)
3. Qamees (upper garment)

For Women:

1. All three above plus:
2. Aurhni (face cover)
3. Seenah-band (chest cover)

The non-pubescent who has reached the age of sensual desires falls into the category of an adult. For their shroud, arrange as many clothes as for an adult.

For younger children:

1. For a small boy: One cloth (izaar) is sufficient, though two cloths (lifafah and izaar) are good
2. For a small girl: Two cloths (lifafah and izaar)

It is better to arrange a complete shroud for both, even for a child who lived only one day.

content.content: The age of sensual desire is estimated at 12 years for boys and 9 years for girls (according to the Islamic calendar). For boys, this means feeling desire for women; for girls, it means when men feel desire looking at her.

body.content: Only Islamic scholars and spiritual guides can be buried with an imamah. It is forbidden to bury ordinary people with an imamah.
It is not permissible to put fragrance containing saffron on male bodies, but it is permissible for female bodies.

sunnahs.title: Shrouding One Who Dies in Ihram

body.content: If a person wearing ihram dies, fragrance should be applied, and the face and head should be covered with the shroud.

Lifafah (Sheet):
- Should be larger than the deceased's height to allow tying from both sides

Izaar (Lower Garment):
- Should extend from the top of the head to the feet
- Smaller than lifafah, without the excess portion used for tying

Qamees (Kafani/Upper Garment):
- Should extend from neck to below the knees
- Equal at front and back
- No sleeves or cuts
- For men: Cut from the shoulders
- For women: Cut towards the chest

Aurhni (For Women):
- Should be 1.5 yards long

Seenah-band (Chest Cover for Women):
- Should extend from the chest to the navel
- Better if it extends to the thighs

content.content: When buying ready-made shrouds, be cautious about the size to avoid wastage (israaf). If purchasing a ready-made shroud, keep extra cloth. If the shroud is bought with the deceased's money, extra cloth will be divided in inheritance.

body.content:
The shroud should be of good quality, equal to the price of clothes that:

1. A man would wear for Eid and Friday prayers
2. A woman would wear when visiting her parents' home

1. After bathing, gently wipe the body with a clean cloth so the shroud doesn't get wet
2. Light joss sticks and move them around the shroud (1, 3, 5, or 7 times maximum)
3. Place down the lifafah (large wrapping sheet) first
4. Place the tahband (izaar) on top of it
5. Place the kafani on top of this
6. Lay the deceased on the shroud and dress them in the kafani
7. Apply fragrance to the beard (or chin) and whole body
8. Apply camphor to the sajdah parts (forehead, nose, hands, knees, feet)
9. Fold the izaar from left side first, then right side
10. Fold the lifafah the same way (right portion remains on top)
11. Tie the shroud at top and bottom to secure it

Additional Steps for Women:

1. After the kafani, divide her hair into two parts and place them on the chest above the kafani
2. Place aurhni below the upper half of the back
3. Fold it above the head and place on the face like a veil, extending to the chest
4. It should reach from half the back to the chest in length and be as wide as the gap between earlobes
5. Fold izaar and lifafah as usual
6. Place seenah-band from chest to thighs and tie with string
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

said: "Whoever receives the news of any funeral, [then] he meets the family members of the deceased and expresses condolences to them, Allah Almighty writes reward of one qeerat for him. Then if he goes with the funeral procession, Allah Almighty writes reward of two qeerat; then if he offers his funeral salah, three qeerat, then if he attends the burial, four [qeerat]; and every qeerat is equal to the Mount Uhud."

sunnahs.title: Attending Funerals is a Muslim's Right

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "There are six rights of a Muslim on a Muslim. (One of them is that) When [a Muslim] dies, the other Muslim should attend his funeral."

sunnahs.title: Blessing for Those Who Attend the Funeral of a Righteous Person

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "When a person who is destined for Paradise dies, Allah Almighty does not punish the people who shoulder his bier, who walk behind it and who offer his funeral salah."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The very first reward a believer will be given after his death is that all the people who have offered his funeral salah will be forgiven."
Sayyiduna Dawood
عليه السلام

humbly asked in the court of Allah Almighty: "Ya Allah Almighty! What is the reward for the one who accompanies a funeral procession only for pleasing You?"

Allah Almighty said: "On the day when he will die, angels will go with his funeral procession, and I will forgive him."

sunnahs.title: Remembrance Upon Seeing a Funeral Procession

body.content: Someone saw Sayyiduna Malik Bin Anas
رَضِيَ اللهُ عَنْهُمَا
in a dream after his demise and asked, "
مَا فَعَلَ اللهُ بِكَ؟
(How did Allah Almighty treat you?)

"

He
رَضِيَ اللهُ عَنْهُ
replied: "He
عزوجل
forgave me because of one kalimah which Sayyiduna Usman Ghani
رَضِيَ اللهُ عَنْهُ
would say after seeing a funeral procession. (That kalimah is
سُبْحَانَ الْحَيِّ الَّذِي لَا يَمُوتُ
(Glory be to the Ever-Living Who never dies)
). Therefore, I also used to say it after seeing a funeral procession. Allah
عزوجل
forgave me because of (saying) this kalimah."

One should offer funeral salah with good intentions, such as:

1. Pleasing Allah Almighty
2. Fulfilling the obligation of offering funeral salah
3. Expressing condolences to the family of the deceased
4. Learning a lesson

While going with a funeral procession, reflect on your own mortality and eventual fate. Think: "I will also be taken one day in the same way as this person is being taken today; I will also be buried in the same way as this person is about to be buried beneath tons of earth."

Such contemplation is an act of worship and a source of earning reward.
Shouldering the funeral bier is a source of earning reward. The beloved Rasool
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
shouldered the funeral bier of Sayyiduna Sa'd Bin Mu'aaz
رَضِيَ اللهُ عَنْهُ

sunnahs.title: Rewards for Shouldering the Funeral Bier

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

said: "Forty grave sins will be removed of the one who shoulders a funeral bier for forty steps."

In another Hadith: "Allah Almighty will absolutely forgive the one who shoulders all four corners of a funeral bier."

sunnahs.title: Proper Method of Shouldering the Bier

body.content:
The Sunnah method is to shoulder a funeral bier from all four corners, one after another, and to walk ten steps each time:

1. First, shoulder the right side of the head side
2. Then the right side of the foot side
3. Then the left side of the head side
4. Finally, the left side of the foot side

When one walks ten steps shouldering each side, he will take forty steps in total.

content.content: Some people announce in a funeral procession, "Walk two steps each." They should instead announce, "Walk ten steps each."

body.content: While shouldering a funeral bier, it is impermissible, haraam and an act leading to Hell to push people deliberately in a way that hurts them, as some do in the funeral procession of a personality or where videos are being made.

sunnahs.title: Carrying a Child's Body and Women's Attendance

body.content:
There is no harm if a single person carries the body of a deceased child in his hands. People may take it into their hands one after another.

It is impermissible and forbidden for women to go with a funeral procession (whether of a child or an adult).

The husband can:

1. Shoulder the funeral bier of his wife
2. Lower her into the grave
3. See her face

Only giving bath and touching the body directly without any cloth in between are forbidden.
It is permissible to recite Kalimah Tayyibah or Kalimah Shahadat or hamd-o-na'at, etc. with a funeral procession in a loud voice.
Allah Almighty has said:
أَلَمْ نَجْعَلِ الْأَرْضَ كِفَاتًا ﴿٢٥﴾ أَحْيَاءً وَأَمْوَاتًا ﴿٢٦﴾
"Did We not make the earth a gathering place? For your living and dead?"

content.content: "In a way that living people are gathered on the earth and the dead inside the earth."

references.source: Kanz-ul-Iman (translation of Quran) (Part 10, Surah Al-Mursalaat, Verses 25,26)

body.content:
It is fard kifayah to bury the deceased (if one person performs it, all are exempted; otherwise, those who received the news but did not participate will be sinners).

It is not permissible to merely place the deceased on the ground and enclose them with walls.
Graves are a blessing from Allah Almighty where the deceased are protected from animals and other forms of disrespect.
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "Bury the deceased beside good people."

content.content: Bury the deceased near righteous people so they receive blessings through proximity. Even if they deserve torment, the righteous may intercede for them, and the mercy descending upon the righteous will also encompass them.

body.content: There is no harm in burying the deceased at night.
It is not permissible to bury more than one person in a single grave without necessity, but it is permitted when necessary.

It is mustahab to place the funeral bier beside the grave in the direction of Qiblah so the deceased can be lowered from that side. Do not place it at the foot of the grave to then move it to the head.

Two or three strong, pious people should step into the grave as required.

A deceased woman should be lowered by her maharim (those with whom her nikah was forever prohibited, like father, brother, son). If unavailable, other relatives should perform this duty, and if they are also absent, pious people should be requested.
Keep a woman's body covered with cloth from when she is lowered into the grave until slabs are placed over the grave.
Recite this supplication when lowering the deceased:
بِسْمِ اللهِ وَعَلَى مِلَّةِ رَسُولِ اللهِ
"With the name of Allah and the religion of the Rasool of Allah
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
(I place him in the grave)."

Lay the deceased on their right side with their face toward the Qiblah.

Untie the knots of the shroud as they are no longer needed, though there is no harm if they remain tied.
The person untying the shroud knots should recite:
اللَّهُمَّ لَا تَحْرِمْنَا أَجْرَهُ وَلَا تَفْتِنَّا بَعْدَهُ
"O Allah! Do not deprive us of his reward and do not put us in trial after him."
Close the grave with unbaked bricks. If the ground is soft, it is permissible to use wooden planks.

It is mustahab to throw earth three times with both hands from the head side. Say with each handful:

First:
مِنْهَا خَلَقْنَاكُمْ
"From it (earth) We created you"
Second:
وَفِيهَا نُعِيدُكُمْ
"And into it We will return you"
Third:
وَمِنْهَا نُخْرِجُكُمْ تَارَةً أُخْرَى
"And from it We will bring you out again"
Then use a spade or similar tool to add the remaining earth.
It is makruh to place more earth on the grave than what was removed from it.
After burial, the earth on hands can either be brushed off or washed.

sunnahs.title: Shape and Care of the Grave

body.content:
Do not make a four-cornered grave; instead, shape it like a camel's hump. It is Sunnah to sprinkle water on the grave after burial. The grave should be a hand-span high or slightly more.

After burial, call out Adhan while standing facing Qiblah at the head of the grave, as it greatly benefits the deceased.

references.source: Derived from Fatawa Razawiyyah, vol. 5, p. 370

body.content:
After burial, it is mustahab to recite:

The first ruku of Surah Al-Baqarah (from
الم
to
مفلحون

) at the head side

The last ruku (from
آمَنَ الرَّسُولُ
to the end of the Surah) at the feet side

sunnahs.title: Staying Near the Grave After Burial

body.content:
It is mustahab to remain near the grave after burial for the time it would take to slaughter a camel and distribute its meat. During this time:

Recite the Holy Quran

Make dua for the deceased

Seek forgiveness for them

Pray for them to remain steadfast in answering Nakirayn's questions

This brings comfort to the deceased and eases their fear of questioning.

It is permissible to place Shajarah or Ahd Naamah (covenant document) in the grave. It is better to make a niche in the Qiblah-facing wall in front of the deceased's face for this.

Writing Ahd Naamah on the shroud is permissible, and one can hope for forgiveness through this practice.

It is also permissible to write
بِسْمِ اللهِ الرَّحْمٰنِ الرَّحِيمِ
on the deceased's chest and forehead.

content.content: A man requested this in his will, and after his death,
بِسْمِ اللهِ الرَّحْمٰنِ الرَّحِيمِ
was written on his chest and forehead. Someone later saw him in a dream and asked about his condition. He said: "When I was laid in the grave, the angels of torment came, but when they saw
بِسْمِ اللهِ الرَّحْمٰنِ الرَّحِيمِ
written on my forehead, they said, 'You have become safe from torment.'"

body.content: Another method is to write
بِسْمِ اللهِ الرَّحْمٰنِ الرَّحِيمِ
on the forehead and the Kalimah Tayyibah (
لَا إِلَٰهَ إِلَّا اللهُ مُحَمَّدٌ رَسُولُ اللهِ
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

) on the chest.

This should be done after giving the deceased bath but before dressing them in the shroud. Write with the forefinger, not using ink.
It is wajib (obligatory) to rebury any bones of the deceased that become exposed from the grave.

references.source: Derived from Fatawa Razawiyyah, vol. 9, p. 406

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "I forbade you from visiting graves, but now you visit graves as it is the cause of being uninterested in the world and makes [one] remember the Hereafter."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "When a person passes by such a grave whose dweller was known to him in the world and he says salam, the deceased recognizes him and replies to his salam."
The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم
said: "The one who visits both of his parents' or either of his parents' graves every Friday will be forgiven and will be written as a pious person."
It is a Sunnah to visit the graves of Muslims. It is a great privilege to visit the shrines of Awliya and honourable martyrs
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
, and conveying reward to them is a liked act and gets one the reward.

If you want to visit [the shrine of a holy man or] the grave of a Muslim, the mustahab act is to first offer 2 rak'aat nafl salah [at a non-makruh time] at your home. Recite 'Ayat-ul-Kursi' one time and 'Surah Al-Ikhlaas' three times after 'Surah Fatihah' in every rak'at and then convey its reward to the grave dweller. Allah Almighty will create nur in the grave of that dead person and will bestow great reward to the one [who has conveyed the reward].
When you visit a blessed shrine or a grave, do not become busy with useless conversation on the way.
Do not kiss the grave and nor should you touch it, but rather stand at some distance from it.
It is haraam to perform sajdah ta'zeemi to the grave, and if it is performed with the intention of performing worship, then it is unbelief.

references.source: Derived from: Fatawa Razawiyyah, vol. 22, p. 423

body.content: In the graveyard, walk on the common path where there were no graves of Muslims in the past. If the walkway has been newly constructed, do not walk on it.

content.content: 'It is haraam to walk on the newly constructed walkway which has been made in a graveyard by demolishing graves. In fact, if a person just presumes [has doubts] that a walkway is new, even then it is impermissible and a sin to walk on it.'

body.content: It has been observed at many shrines of blessed Awliya that the graves of Muslims are demolished and a floor is made so that visitors can be facilitated. On such a floor, lying, walking, standing, sitting for zikr and the recitation, etc. are all haraam. Recite Fatihah from a distance.

When you visit a grave, stand where the face of the deceased is. For this, come from the side of the feet of the deceased so that you are within the sight. Do not come from the head side as the deceased will have to see you by raising his head.
Stand in the graveyard in a way that your back is in the direction of Qiblah and the face is in the direction of the faces of the grave dwellers. After this recite the following:
السَّلَامُ عَلَيْكُمْ أَهْلَ الدِّيَارِ مِنَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ وَالْمُسْلِمِينَ، وَإِنَّا إِنْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ بِكُمْ لَاحِقُونَ
Translation: O grave dwellers! Peace be upon you! May Allah Almighty forgive us and you! You have come before us, and we are going to come after you.

references.source: Derived from, Mirqat-ul-Mafatih, vol. 4, p. 253, under the Hadith 1765

body.content: For him who recites the following supplication after entering a graveyard:
اللَّهُمَّ رَبَّ الْأَجْسَادِ الْبَالِيَةِ، وَالْعِظَامِ النَّخِرَةِ، الَّتِي خَرَجَتْ مِنَ الدُّنْيَا وَهِيَ بِكَ مُؤْمِنَةٌ، أَدْخِلْ عَلَيْهَا رَوْحًا مِنْ عِندِكَ، وَسَلَامًا مِنِّي
Translation: O Allah Almighty! O the Lord of decomposed bodies and decayed bones! Have mercy on those who have left the world in the state of faith and convey my salaam to them.
All the believers who have passed away from Sayyiduna Adam عليه السلام until that day will pray for his forgiveness.

references.source: Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah, vol. 8, p. 257

sunnahs.title: Reciting Quranic Surahs for the Dead

body.content: The beloved Prophet
صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّم

has said: "The one who enters a graveyard and then recites 'Surah Al-Fatihah', 'Surah Al-Ikhlaas' and 'Surah Al-Takasur' and then makes the following prayer: 'O Allah! Whatever Quran I have recited, convey its reward to the believing men and women of this graveyard', all those believers will be his [i.e. the one who has conveyed the reward] intercessors on the Judgement Day."

sunnahs.title: Reciting Surah Al-Ikhlaas for the Dead

body.content: It is stated in a blessed Hadith: "The one who recites 'Surah Al-Ikhlaas' [i.e.
قُلْ هُوَ اللهُ أَحَدٌ
] eleven times (complete Surah) and then conveys its reward to the dead will get the reward equal to the number of the dead."

A lighted joss stick should not be placed on a grave as it is disrespect and a bad omen. However, if you want to make the environment fragrant for visitors, place a joss stick near the grave on an empty space as making the environment fragrant for others is a desirable act.

references.source: Summarised from: Fatawa Razawiyyah, vol. 9, pp. 482, 525, extracted

body.content: A'la Hazrat
رَحْمَةُ اللهِ عَلَيْه
has stated: It has been narrated in Sahih Muslim on the authority of Sayyiduna Amr Bin 'Aas
رَضِيَ اللهُ عَنْهُ
that he said to his son in his last breath: "When I die, neither any woman who does wailing over the deceased should go with me, nor should fire go [with me]."

Do not place an oil lamp, a lighted candle, etc. on a grave. However, if the light is required for people to walk on the way or to recite the Holy Quran in the [darkness of] night, a candle or an oil lamp can be placed beside a grave on an empty space. The empty space should not be the place where there was a grave that has now been demolished.
The following four days are better for visiting graves: Monday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

content.content: Visiting graves is preferable after Fajr Salah on Friday.

body.content: It is preferable to visit graves on the blessed nights, especially Layla-tul-Bara'at.
Similarly, it is preferable to visit graves during blessed days as well.
